General Syntax

On this page

Primitive Types ​

Baseline Feature
Version: 0.1.2
Status: ✅ Implemented
Test: 00_base_feats/02_primitive_types.vx

Overview ​

Primitive types are the fundamental building blocks of the Vex type system. They represent scalar values and are directly supported by hardware.

Integer Types ​

Signed Integers ​

Fixed-size signed integers with two's complement representation:

TypeSizeRangeDefault
i88 bits-128 to 127❌
i1616 bits-32,768 to 32,767❌
i3232 bits-2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647✅
i6464 bits-9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807❌
i128128 bits-2^127 to 2^127-1❌

Default: Integer literals without type annotation default to i32

Examples:

rust
let small: i8 = 127;
let medium: i16 = 32767;
let normal = 42;                    // i32 (default)
let large: i64 = 9223372036854775807;
let huge: i128 = 170141183460469231731687303715884105727;

Negative values:

rust
let neg_byte: i8 = -128;
let neg_int: i32 = -2147483648;

Unsigned Integers ​

Fixed-size unsigned integers (non-negative only):

TypeSizeRangeDefault
u88 bits0 to 255❌
u1616 bits0 to 65,535❌
u3232 bits0 to 4,294,967,295❌
u6464 bits0 to 18,446,744,073,709,551,615❌
u128128 bits0 to 2^128-1❌

Examples:

rust
let byte_val: u8 = 255;
let port: u16 = 8080;
let count: u32 = 4294967295;
let big_num: u64 = 18446744073709551615;

Type Aliases ​

rust
byte        // Alias for u8

Implementation:

AST: vex-ast/src/types.rs

rust
#[derive(Debug, Clone, PartialEq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
pub enum Type {
    // Primitive integers
    I8, I16, I32, I64, I128,
    U8, U16, U32, U64, U128,
    // ...
}

Codegen: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/types/primitives.rs

rust
pub(crate) fn get_int_type(
    &self,
    ty: &Type,
) -> Result<IntType<'ctx>, String> {
    match ty {
        Type::I8 | Type::U8 => Ok(self.context.i8_type()),
        Type::I16 | Type::U16 => Ok(self.context.i16_type()),
        Type::I32 | Type::U32 => Ok(self.context.i32_type()),
        Type::I64 | Type::U64 => Ok(self.context.i64_type()),
        Type::I128 | Type::U128 => Ok(self.context.i128_type()),
        _ => Err(format!("Not an integer type: {:?}", ty)),
    }
}

Floating-Point Types ​

IEEE 754 floating-point numbers:

TypeSizePrecisionRange (approx)Default
f1616 bitsHalf±6.5×10^4❌
f3232 bitsSingle±3.4×10^38❌
f6464 bitsDouble±1.7×10^308✅

Default: Float literals default to f64

Examples:

rust
let half: f32 = 3.14;
let double: f64 = 2.718281828;
let pi = 3.14159;           // f64 (default)

Special values:

rust
let inf: f64 = 1.0 / 0.0;           // Infinity
let neg_inf: f64 = -1.0 / 0.0;      // -Infinity
let not_a_num: f64 = 0.0 / 0.0;     // NaN

Implementation:

AST:

rust
pub enum Type {
    F16, F32, F64,
    // ...
}

Codegen:

rust
pub(crate) fn get_float_type(
    &self,
    ty: &Type,
) -> Result<FloatType<'ctx>, String> {
    match ty {
        Type::F16 => Ok(self.context.f16_type()),
        Type::F32 => Ok(self.context.f32_type()),
        Type::F64 => Ok(self.context.f64_type()),
        _ => Err(format!("Not a float type: {:?}", ty)),
    }
}

Boolean Type ​

Two-valued logic type:

rust
let yes: bool = true;
let no: bool = false;

Size: 1 byte (i8 in LLVM)
Values: true (1), false (0)

Examples:

rust
let flag = true;
let is_valid: bool = false;

if flag {
    // executed
}

let result = yes && !no;    // true

Implementation:

AST:

rust
pub enum Type {
    Bool,
    // ...
}

Codegen:

rust
Type::Bool => Ok(self.context.bool_type().as_basic_type_enum()),

String Type ​

UTF-8 encoded text:

rust
let text: string = "Hello, World!";
let empty: string = "";
let name = "Alice";         // string (inferred)

Encoding: UTF-8
Memory: Heap-allocated, reference-counted (planned)
Representation: Pointer to buffer + length

Examples:

rust
let greeting = "Hello";
let message = f"Welcome, {greeting}!";

Implementation:

AST:

rust
pub enum Type {
    String,
    // ...
}

Codegen:

rust
Type::String => {
    // Struct: { ptr: i8*, len: i64 }
    let i8_type = self.context.i8_type();
    let i64_type = self.context.i64_type();
    let ptr_type = i8_type.ptr_type(AddressSpace::default());
    let struct_type = self.context.struct_type(
        &[ptr_type.into(), i64_type.into()],
        false,
    );
    Ok(struct_type.as_basic_type_enum())
}

Special Types ​

Nil Type (Unit) ​

Represents absence of value:

rust
let nothing = nil;

fn no_return() {
    // Returns nil implicitly
}

Type: () (unit type)
Size: 0 bytes
Use: Functions without return value, optional absence

Implementation:

rust
pub enum Type {
    Nil,  // Unit type
    // ...
}

Error Type ​

Represents error values:

rust
let err: error = some_error();

Note: Full error handling system in progress

Implementation:

rust
pub enum Type {
    Error,
    // ...
}

Byte Type (Alias) ​

rust
byte    // Alias for u8

Used for raw byte data, ASCII characters.

Type Inference ​

Compiler infers types when not explicitly specified:

rust
let x = 42;         // i32 (integer default)
let y = 3.14;       // f64 (float default)
let z = true;       // bool
let s = "text";     // string

Explicit annotations:

rust
let a: i64 = 42;
let b: f32 = 3.14;
let c: u8 = 255;

Type Conversions ​

Primitive types require explicit conversion (no implicit widening):

rust
let x: i32 = 42;
let y: i64 = x as i64;          // Explicit cast
let z: f64 = y as f64;          // i64 -> f64

let byte: u8 = 255;
let int: i32 = byte as i32;     // u8 -> i32

Implementation Details ​

LLVM Type Mapping ​

Vex TypeLLVM Type
i8, u8i8
i16, u16i16
i32, u32i32
i64, u64i64
i128, u128i128
f16half
f32float
f64double
booli1 (or i8)
string{i8*, i64}
nilvoid

Codegen: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/types/conversion.rs ​

rust
pub(crate) fn ast_type_to_llvm(
    &self,
    ty: &Type,
) -> Result<BasicTypeEnum<'ctx>, String> {
    match ty {
        Type::I8 | Type::U8 => Ok(self.context.i8_type().into()),
        Type::I16 | Type::U16 => Ok(self.context.i16_type().into()),
        Type::I32 | Type::U32 => Ok(self.context.i32_type().into()),
        Type::I64 | Type::U64 => Ok(self.context.i64_type().into()),
        Type::I128 | Type::U128 => Ok(self.context.i128_type().into()),
        Type::F16 => Ok(self.context.f16_type().into()),
        Type::F32 => Ok(self.context.f32_type().into()),
        Type::F64 => Ok(self.context.f64_type().into()),
        Type::Bool => Ok(self.context.bool_type().into()),
        Type::String => {
            // {i8*, i64} struct
            self.get_string_struct_type()
        }
        Type::Nil => Err("Nil type has no LLVM representation".to_string()),
        _ => Err(format!("Unknown type: {:?}", ty)),
    }
}

Examples from Test ​

From Specifications/Tests/00_base_feats/02_primitive_types.vx:

rust
fn main(): i32 {
    // Signed integers
    let i8_val: i8 = 127;
    assert(i8_val == 127, "i8 type");

    let i16_val: i16 = 32767;
    assert(i16_val == 32767, "i16 type");

    let i32_val: i32 = 2147483647;
    assert(i32_val == 2147483647, "i32 type");

    let i64_val: i64 = 9223372036854775807;
    assert(i64_val > 0, "i64 type");

    // Unsigned integers
    let u8_val: u8 = 255;
    assert(u8_val == 255, "u8 type");

    let u16_val: u16 = 65535;
    assert(u16_val == 65535, "u16 type");

    let u32_val: u32 = 4294967295;
    assert(u32_val > 0, "u32 type");

    let u64_val: u64 = 18446744073709551615;
    assert(u64_val > 0, "u64 type");

    // Floating point
    let f32_val: f32 = 3.14;
    assert(f32_val > 3.0, "f32 type");

    let f64_val: f64 = 2.718281828;
    assert(f64_val > 2.7, "f64 type");

    // Boolean
    let bool_val: bool = true;
    assert(bool_val, "bool type");

    return 0;
}
